title: Expedites the time for consideration by the office of victim services of claims by elderly crime victims
summary: Expedites the time for consideration by the crime victims board of claims by elderly victims; removes the monetary limitation on awards made for the cost of repair or replacement of essential personal property in the case of medically necessary life-sustaining equipment for an elderly victim which was lost or damaged as the direct result of a crime.

                                   February 1, 2011

       Introduced  by  M.  of  A.  ENGLEBRIGHT -- read once and referred to the
         Committee on Governmental Operations

       AN ACT to amend the executive law, in relation to certain  crime  victim
         compensation benefits for elderly victims

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. Subdivision 1 of  section  627  of  the  executive  law  is
    2  amended by adding a new paragraph (e-1) to read as follows:
    3    (E-1)  EXPEDITED  DETERMINATION  OF  CLAIMS WITH RESPECT TO AN ELDERLY
    4  VICTIM WITHIN FORTY-FIVE DAYS OF THE  DATE  UPON  WHICH  THE  CLAIM  WAS
    5  ACCEPTED FOR FILING;
    6    S  2. Subdivision 9 of section 631 of the executive law, as amended by
    7  section 30 of part E of chapter 58 of the laws of 1998,  is  amended  to
    8  read as follows:
    9    9.  [Any]  EXCEPT  IN  THE CASE OF MEDICALLY NECESSARY LIFE-SUSTAINING
   10  EQUIPMENT FOR AN ELDERLY VICTIM WHICH WAS LOST OR DAMAGED AS THE  DIRECT
   11  RESULT  OF A CRIME, ANY award made for the cost of repair or replacement
   12  of essential personal  property,  including  cash  losses  of  essential
   13  personal  property,  shall  be  limited  to  an  amount  of five hundred
   14  dollars, except that all cash  losses  of  essential  personal  property
   15  shall be limited to the amount of one hundred dollars.
   16    S  3. This act shall take effect on the first of January next succeed-
   17  ing the date on which it shall have become a law.



        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
